elements.content: In this work, two new benzothiadiazole-derived complexes, namely, [Zn0.5(TBC)­(H2O)] (1, TBC = 4-cyano-7-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)­benzothiadiazole) and [Cd­(TBC)­(N3)­(H2O)] n (2), were successfully obtained by the in situ click synthetic methods in hydrothermal conditions. While complex 1 shows a mononuclear structure that can be extended to the three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network by the intermolecular hydrogen bonds and N–S interactions, for 2, it is a coordination polymer comprised of undulated two-dimensional layers with a (8)­(84•122) topological network, where the adjacent layers are stacked to form a 3D supramolecular framework sustained by interlayer N–S interactions. Comparing to the single emission of 1 centered at 570 nm, 2 showed the dual emissions, which were centered at 490 and 568 nm, respectively. Such phenomenon resulted from the different decay procedures for the π → π* states of monomeric benzothiadiazole species (ππ* state) between 1 and 2. Significantly, on the one hand, because of the deprotonated tetrazole group in the organic linker, 1 is capable of sensing the changes of pH, showing the reversible fluorescence on–off responses in acidic ambience. On the other hand, in comparison with in 1, the coordinated tetrazole group was close to neutral; therefore, 2 exhibited the self-referencing fluorescence response in an alkaline environment.
elements.clean_text: In this work, two new benzothiadiazole-derived complexes, namely, [Zn0.5(TBC)(H2O)] (1, TBC = 4-cyano-7-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)benzothiadiazole) and [Cd(TBC)(N3)(H2O)] n  (2), were successfully obtained by the in situ click synthetic methods in hydrothermal conditions. While complex 1 shows a mononuclear structure that can be extended to the three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network by the intermolecular hydrogen bonds and N-S interactions, for 2, it is a coordination polymer comprised of undulated two-dimensional layers with a (8)(84⋅122) topological network, where the adjacent layers are stacked to form a 3D supramolecular framework sustained by interlayer N-S interactions. Comparing to the single emission of 1 centered at 570 nm, 2 showed the dual emissions, which were centered at 490 and 568 nm, respectively. Such phenomenon resulted from the different decay procedures for the π → π* states of monomeric benzothiadiazole species (ππ* state) between 1 and 2. Significantly, on the one hand, because of the deprotonated tetrazole group in the organic linker, 1 is capable of sensing the changes of pH, showing the reversible fluorescence on-off responses in acidic ambience. On the other hand, in comparison with in 1, the coordinated tetrazole group was close to neutral; therefore, 2 exhibited the self-referencing fluorescence response in an alkaline environment.

elements.content:
Herein, we first reported some interesting examples of pH-responsible benzothiadiazole-derived coordination polymers synthesized via a situ click method.

Introduction

Recently, optical-functional coordination polymer (CP) is a rapidly growing class of crystalline material with great potential application across a broad range of areas. Especially, luminescent CP is recently a potential chemical probe to respond to different materials, including biotarget, environmental toxin, explosive, volatile organic compound (VOC), and ion in aqueous ambience, which has been rapidly developed by using the design principles of crystal engineering and structure–property correlations. Since the first pH-dependent fluorescence example reported by Zhou and co-workers in 2013, the study of pH-responsive CP has became one of the important parts in this area. Actually, because of the multifaceted feature of its structure, CP usually displays a broad range of luminescent behavior, which is resulted from different origins, including the linker, coordinated metal ion, antenna effect, excimer and exciplex formation, and guest molecule. Among these, the luminescence of the organic linker or central metal ion is the most important and extensive. For the metal-based emissive CP system, the icon of pH-responsive material is the lanthanide-CP system. However, chromophore-derived system is a more convenient choice for using various transition-metal ions in this area, according to the photophysical nature of d-electrons (where nonradiative d–d transitions are the major barrier) or fully filled d-orbitals (like in Zn­(II), where there are absent metal-to-ligand charge transfer states or ligand-to-metal charge transfer states).
elements.clean_text:
Herein, we first reported some interesting examples of pH-responsible benzothiadiazole-derived coordination polymers synthesized via a situ click method.

Introduction

Recently, optical-functional coordination polymer (CP) is a rapidly growing class of crystalline material with great potential application across a broad range of areas. Especially, luminescent CP is recently a potential chemical probe to respond to different materials, including biotarget, environmental toxin, explosive, volatile organic compound (VOC), and ion in aqueous ambience, which has been rapidly developed by using the design principles of crystal engineering and structure-property correlations. Since the first pH-dependent fluorescence example reported by Zhou and co-workers in 2013, the study of pH-responsive CP has became one of the important parts in this area. Actually, because of the multifaceted feature of its structure, CP usually displays a broad range of luminescent behavior, which is resulted from different origins, including the linker, coordinated metal ion, antenna effect, excimer and exciplex formation, and guest molecule. Among these, the luminescence of the organic linker or central metal ion is the most important and extensive. For the metal-based emissive CP system, the icon of pH-responsive material is the lanthanide-CP system. However, chromophore-derived system is a more convenient choice for using various transition-metal ions in this area, according to the photophysical nature of d-electrons (where nonradiative d-d transitions are the major barrier) or fully filled d-orbitals (like in Zn(II), where there are absent metal-to-ligand charge transfer states or ligand-to-metal charge transfer states).

elements.content: As we know, on the one hand, benzothiadiazole (BTD) is an efficient chromophore with high fluorescence quantum yield. On the other hand, the highly polarized feature of BTD species usually supports it to afford well-ordered crystal structure by intermolecular interactions. Since 2014, the first BTD-based metal–organic framework (MOF) example was reported by Chen and co-workers. Currently, several groups participated in the studies of BTD-derived MOF materials, which showed the attractive properties in different area, especially when the pH-sensitive group was functionalized on the BTD species, which would distinctly show the spectroscopic responses to the changing pH in a relatively broad range, even in a MOF material. However, according to the literature, the uncoordinated nitrogen atoms in the organic linker of a CP could be the contribution of spectroscopic changes depending on the different pH ambience. Besides, in the situ generated tetrazolate coordination architectures, the tetrazole ligand acts as either a multidentate or a bridging building block, where most coordination modes show the existence of uncoordinated nitrogen atoms.
elements.clean_text: As we know, on the one hand, benzothiadiazole (BTD) is an efficient chromophore with high fluorescence quantum yield. On the other hand, the highly polarized feature of BTD species usually supports it to afford well-ordered crystal structure by intermolecular interactions. Since 2014, the first BTD-based metal-organic framework (MOF) example was reported by Chen and co-workers. Currently, several groups participated in the studies of BTD-derived MOF materials, which showed the attractive properties in different area, especially when the pH-sensitive group was functionalized on the BTD species, which would distinctly show the spectroscopic responses to the changing pH in a relatively broad range, even in a MOF material. However, according to the literature, the uncoordinated nitrogen atoms in the organic linker of a CP could be the contribution of spectroscopic changes depending on the different pH ambience. Besides, in the situ generated tetrazolate coordination architectures, the tetrazole ligand acts as either a multidentate or a bridging building block, where most coordination modes show the existence of uncoordinated nitrogen atoms.

elements.content: Herein, in this work, two new BTD-derived complexes, namely, [Zn0.5(TBC)­(H2O)] (1, TBC = 4-cyano-7-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)­benzothiadiazole) and [Cd­(TBC)­(N3)­(H2O)] n (2), were successfully obtained by the in situ click reactions with 4,7-dicyano-benzenethiazole and metal salts in hydrothermal conditions (). The structural analyses indicated that complex 1 was a mononuclear structure that was extended to the three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network by the intermolecular hydrogen bond and N–S interactions. For CP 2, it showed the undulated two-dimensional (2D) layers with an (8)­(84•122) topological network, where the adjacent layers were arranged in a 3D supramolecular framework by the interlayer N–S interactions. Because of the different decay procedure for the π → π* state of monomeric BTD species (ππ* state) in 1 and 2, respectively, while 1 showed the single emission centered at 570 nm, 2 showed the dual emissions, which were centered at 490 and 568 nm, respectively. As we expect, both of them are pH-sensitive, showing the reversible fluorescence responses. Because of the different proton-withdrawing capability of tetrazole group in the organic linker, 1 showed the reversible fluorescence on–off responses in acidic ambience, whereas 2 exhibited the self-referencing fluorescence response in an alkaline environment.
elements.clean_text: Herein, in this work, two new BTD-derived complexes, namely, [Zn0.5(TBC)(H2O)] (1, TBC = 4-cyano-7-(1H-tetrazol-5-yl)benzothiadiazole) and [Cd(TBC)(N3)(H2O)] n  (2), were successfully obtained by the in situ click reactions with 4,7-dicyano-benzenethiazole and metal salts in hydrothermal conditions (). The structural analyses indicated that complex 1 was a mononuclear structure that was extended to the three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network by the intermolecular hydrogen bond and N-S interactions. For CP 2, it showed the undulated two-dimensional (2D) layers with an (8)(84⋅122) topological network, where the adjacent layers were arranged in a 3D supramolecular framework by the interlayer N-S interactions. Because of the different decay procedure for the π → π* state of monomeric BTD species (ππ* state) in 1 and 2, respectively, while 1 showed the single emission centered at 570 nm, 2 showed the dual emissions, which were centered at 490 and 568 nm, respectively. As we expect, both of them are pH-sensitive, showing the reversible fluorescence responses. Because of the different proton-withdrawing capability of tetrazole group in the organic linker, 1 showed the reversible fluorescence on-off responses in acidic ambience, whereas 2 exhibited the self-referencing fluorescence response in an alkaline environment.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Procedures of 1 and 2

elements.content: Although there were two carbonitrile groups in the precursor of organic linker PL, the structural analysis indicated that only one wing was transformed to the tetrazole group in complex 1. As shown in , complex 1 consists of an [M­(TBC)2] neutral mononuclear structure, crystallizing in the monoclinic space group C2/c (), where its asymmetric unit is composed of half of a discrete [Zn­(TBC)2(H2O)2)] species.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures of 1

Although there were two carbonitrile groups in the precursor of organic linker PL, the structural analysis indicated that only one wing was transformed to the tetrazole group in complex 1. As shown in , complex 1 consists of an [M(TBC)2] neutral mononuclear structure, crystallizing in the monoclinic space group C2/c (), where its asymmetric unit is composed of half of a discrete [Zn(TBC)2(H2O)2)] species.

View of Zn­(II) coordination environment in 1 and schematic representation illustrating the 3D supramolecular network of complex 1 based on 44-subnets by hydrogen bonding (2D 44-subnet layer formed by hydrogen bonding, red dotted line) and interlayer N–S interactions (light blue dotted line) (All the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 1  View of Zn(II) coordination environment in 1 and schematic representation illustrating the 3D supramolecular network of complex 1 based on 44-subnets by hydrogen bonding (2D 44-subnet layer formed by hydrogen bonding, red dotted line) and interlayer N-S interactions (light blue dotted line) (All the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: In detail, the Zn­(II) ion located in the symmetry center that was chelated by two deprotonatedly planar TBC ligands with the trans configuration. Two BTD nitrogen atoms and two tetrazole nitrogen atoms from different organic linkers build the equatorial plane around the Zn­(II) ions for 1 (Zn1–N2 2.318(3) Å, Zn1–N3 2.025 (2) Å, Table S1). Meanwhile, the central Zn­(II) ion also was coordinated by two water molecules at the equatorial axial positions (Zn1–O1 2.108(2) Å, Table S1), giving rise to its octahedral geometry. Although the mononuclear structure of 1 is similar to that of the complex [Zn-(pzta)2(H2O)2] (pzta = pyrazinyl tetrazolate), there were remarkable differences in the intermolecular interactions among them, which were the driving force to form the 3D supramolecular networks. As shown in , each discrete [Zn­(TBC)2(H2O)2)] unit linked four adjacent ones through the hydrogen bonds of O1···N5 (2.8362(35) Å, Table S3) and O1···N6 (2.7645(35) Å, Table S3) to form four-connected sublayer 44-nets. On the one hand, interestingly, the adjacent 44-subnets in 1 were further linked by the interlayer N–S interactions (S1···N7 3.7240(51) Å) to establish a regular 3D supramolecular framework (). On the other hand, the TGA curve of 1 showed that the first weight loss occurred at 165 °C, corresponding to the stepwise removal of the coordinated water molecules (Figure S1). Such result indicated that there was no free solvent molecule in the structure, consistent with the crystal structural analysis. Besides, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of 1 was perfectly consistent with the simulated one (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text: In detail, the Zn(II) ion located in the symmetry center that was chelated by two deprotonatedly planar TBC ligands with the trans configuration. Two BTD nitrogen atoms and two tetrazole nitrogen atoms from different organic linkers build the equatorial plane around the Zn(II) ions for 1 (Zn1-N2 2.318(3) Å, Zn1-N3 2.025 (2) Å, Table S1). Meanwhile, the central Zn(II) ion also was coordinated by two water molecules at the equatorial axial positions (Zn1-O1 2.108(2) Å, Table S1), giving rise to its octahedral geometry. Although the mononuclear structure of 1 is similar to that of the complex [Zn-(pzta)2(H2O)2] (pzta = pyrazinyl tetrazolate), there were remarkable differences in the intermolecular interactions among them, which were the driving force to form the 3D supramolecular networks. As shown in , each discrete [Zn(TBC)2(H2O)2)] unit linked four adjacent ones through the hydrogen bonds of O1⋅⋅⋅N5 (2.8362(35) Å, Table S3) and O1⋅⋅⋅N6 (2.7645(35) Å, Table S3) to form four-connected sublayer 44-nets. On the one hand, interestingly, the adjacent 44-subnets in 1 were further linked by the interlayer N-S interactions (S1⋅⋅⋅N7 3.7240(51) Å) to establish a regular 3D supramolecular framework (). On the other hand, the TGA curve of 1 showed that the first weight loss occurred at 165 °C, corresponding to the stepwise removal of the coordinated water molecules (Figure S1). Such result indicated that there was no free solvent molecule in the structure, consistent with the crystal structural analysis. Besides, the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of 1 was perfectly consistent with the simulated one (Figure S2).

elements.content: Similarly, when the metal salt was replaced by Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O with excess NaN3, the structural analysis of complex 2 also indicated that only one carbonitrile group was transformed to the tetrazole group in the planar TBC ligand, which was capable of coordinating two Cd­(II) ion simultaneously (a). However, as shown in b, complex 2 is a CP, crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Meanwhile, the six coordinated Cd­(II) ions locate in the asymmetry center in a slightly distorted octahedral geometry, where one chelated TBC ligand, one noncheltaed TBC ligand, one water molecule, and two azide anions are surrounding the central metal ion.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of 2

Similarly, when the metal salt was replaced by Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O with excess NaN3, the structural analysis of complex 2 also indicated that only one carbonitrile group was transformed to the tetrazole group in the planar TBC ligand, which was capable of coordinating two Cd(II) ion simultaneously (a). However, as shown in b, complex 2 is a CP, crystallizing in the monoclinic space group P21/c. Meanwhile, the six coordinated Cd(II) ions locate in the asymmetry center in a slightly distorted octahedral geometry, where one chelated TBC ligand, one noncheltaed TBC ligand, one water molecule, and two azide anions are surrounding the central metal ion.

elements.content: (a) Coordination mode of organic ligand in complex 2. (b) Coordination environment of Cd ion in complex 2 (All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination mode of organic ligand in complex 2. (b) Coordination environment of Cd ion in complex 2 (All hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: Interestingly, the μ2-N3 – in 2 plays a role as the bridge ligand, which is the important support to form the undulated 2D layer of 2 with a (8)­(84•122) topological network (). According to the literature for CP by in situ click synthesis, such an interesting coordination mode only was present in a few Cd­(II)-tetrazole CP systems. Especially, the adjacent layers were arranged in a 3D supramolecular framework by the interlayer N–S interactions (S1···N5 3.1423(30) Å and S1···N6 3.7614(58) Å). According to the TGA curve of 2, there was no free solvent molecule in this structure. Meanwhile, PXRD pattern of 2 was consistent with the simulated one (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, the μ2-N3 - in 2 plays a role as the bridge ligand, which is the important support to form the undulated 2D layer of 2 with a (8)(84⋅122) topological network (). According to the literature for CP by in situ click synthesis, such an interesting coordination mode only was present in a few Cd(II)-tetrazole CP systems. Especially, the adjacent layers were arranged in a 3D supramolecular framework by the interlayer N-S interactions (S1⋅⋅⋅N5 3.1423(30) Å and S1⋅⋅⋅N6 3.7614(58) Å). According to the TGA curve of 2, there was no free solvent molecule in this structure. Meanwhile, PXRD pattern of 2 was consistent with the simulated one (Figure S3).

elements.content: Schematic representation illustrating the 3D supramolecular network of complex 2 based on the undulated 2D (8)­(84•122)-subnets by interlayer N–S interactions (red and magenta dotted line) (All the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).
elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic representation illustrating the 3D supramolecular network of complex 2 based on the undulated 2D (8)(84⋅122)-subnets by interlayer N-S interactions (red and magenta dotted line) (All the hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity).

elements.content: As we know, BTD is an excellent fluorescent chromophore. In this work, the solid-state UV–vis absorption and emission spectra (a,b) of all samples were measured and analyzed to understand the connection between structure and photophysical property in such system before the pH-response studies of 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties

As we know, BTD is an excellent fluorescent chromophore. In this work, the solid-state UV-vis absorption and emission spectra (a,b) of all samples were measured and analyzed to understand the connection between structure and photophysical property in such system before the pH-response studies of 1 and 2.

elements.content: UV–Vis absorption and emission spectra of 1 (a, single emission, excited at 360 nm) and 2 (b, dual emission) in solid state at room temperature. The speculated emission mechanism model (c) in complex 1 and (d) of complex 2 in solid state. (ππ* (BTD): π → π* excited state of monomeric BTD species; ILCT: π­(tetrazole) → π*­(BTD-CN) excited state; F: fluorescence; GS: ground state; IC: internal conversion; NID: nonirradiation decay; and S1: the lowest-energy singlet excited state).
elements.clean_text: 4  UV-Vis absorption and emission spectra of 1 (a, single emission, excited at 360 nm) and 2 (b, dual emission) in solid state at room temperature. The speculated emission mechanism model (c) in complex 1 and (d) of complex 2 in solid state. (ππ* (BTD): π → π* excited state of monomeric BTD species; ILCT: π(tetrazole) → π*(BTD-CN) excited state; F: fluorescence; GS: ground state; IC: internal conversion; NID: nonirradiation decay; and S1: the lowest-energy singlet excited state).

elements.content: In this work, both complexes 1 and 2 showed the prolonged tails of absorption around 530 and 537 nm, respectively (). As described above, TBC is planar, which easily triggers the π–π stacking interaction in solid state. Especially, on the one hand, in complex 1 (Figure S4a), the organic linkers lie in parallel molecular planes to form the dimer in which the BTD units arrange in the same direction (syn-dimer of BTD; the transannular distance is of 3.39 Å). On the other hand, the dilute aqueous solution of complex 1 (Figure S5a) showed that there was a weak absorption at ∼465 nm resulting from the interligand charge transfer (ILCT) (π­(tetrazole) → π*­(BTD-CN)) transition, and over 500 nm no absorption band was observed. Hence, such absorption band around 530 nm (ν = 18 870 cm–1) is clearly resulted from the transition of syn-dimer. In contrast, as shown in Figure S4b, only the dimer in which the BTD units arrange in the opposite direction (anti-dimer of BTD; the transannular distance is of 3.37 Å). Such anti-dimer showed the slightly lower energy absorption band centered at 537 nm (ν = 18 620 cm–1), which was consistent with the reported case in 2010. Interestingly, comparing to small difference in absorption spectra, there was a significant difference of luminescence behavior between 1 and 2. As shown in a, complex 1 displayed the single emission, which was centered at 570 nm (ν = 17 540 cm–1). According to the excitation spectrum of 1 (Figure S6a), this emission is originated from the ILCT (π­(tetrazole) → π*­(BTD-CN)) transition, not the excited state of BTD syn-dimer species. Furthermore, without the contribution of BTD syn-dimer, the ILCT emission of 1 in water was hypsochromically shifted to 537 nm (ν = 18 620 cm–1, Figure S5b). However, 2 showed the totally different emission behavior (dual emission, b), where two emission peaks were centered at 490 (ν = 20 410 cm–1) and 568 nm (ν = 17 605 cm–1), respectively. Similarly, the former is ascribed to the π → π* state of monomeric BTD species (ππ* state), while the latter is resulted from the ILCT (π­(tetrazole) → π*­(BTD-CN)) state (Figure S6b). Besides, under the irradiation at 530 nm, neither 1 nor 2 shows the dimer emission. Because the large Stoke’s shift is common in BTD-based species, such emission was probably in near-infrared (NIR) range, which was easily quenched in concentrated solid state.
elements.clean_text: In this work, both complexes 1 and 2 showed the prolonged tails of absorption around 530 and 537 nm, respectively (). As described above, TBC is planar, which easily triggers the π-π stacking interaction in solid state. Especially, on the one hand, in complex 1 (Figure S4a), the organic linkers lie in parallel molecular planes to form the dimer in which the BTD units arrange in the same direction (syn-dimer of BTD; the transannular distance is of 3.39 Å). On the other hand, the dilute aqueous solution of complex 1 (Figure S5a) showed that there was a weak absorption at ~465 nm resulting from the interligand charge transfer (ILCT) (π(tetrazole) → π*(BTD-CN)) transition, and over 500 nm no absorption band was observed. Hence, such absorption band around 530 nm (ν = 18870 cm-1) is clearly resulted from the transition of syn-dimer. In contrast, as shown in Figure S4b, only the dimer in which the BTD units arrange in the opposite direction (anti-dimer of BTD; the transannular distance is of 3.37 Å). Such anti-dimer showed the slightly lower energy absorption band centered at 537 nm (ν = 18 620 cm-1), which was consistent with the reported case in 2010. Interestingly, comparing to small difference in absorption spectra, there was a significant difference of luminescence behavior between 1 and 2. As shown in a, complex 1 displayed the single emission, which was centered at 570 nm (ν = 17540 cm-1). According to the excitation spectrum of 1 (Figure S6a), this emission is originated from the ILCT (π(tetrazole) → π*(BTD-CN)) transition, not the excited state of BTD syn-dimer species. Furthermore, without the contribution of BTD syn-dimer, the ILCT emission of 1 in water was hypsochromically shifted to 537 nm (ν = 18620 cm-1, Figure S5b). However, 2 showed the totally different emission behavior (dual emission, b), where two emission peaks were centered at 490 (ν = 20 410 cm-1) and 568 nm (ν = 17605 cm-1), respectively. Similarly, the former is ascribed to the π → π* state of monomeric BTD species (ππ* state), while the latter is resulted from the ILCT (π(tetrazole) → π*(BTD-CN)) state (Figure S6b). Besides, under the irradiation at 530 nm, neither 1 nor 2 shows the dimer emission. Because the large Stoke's shift is common in BTD-based species, such emission was probably in near-infrared (NIR) range, which was easily quenched in concentrated solid state.

elements.content: Herein, we surmised that, because mononuclear complex 1 is relatively flexible, the molecular vibrational deactivation was the main non-irradiation decay process of excited state in higher energy level. At the same time, the excitation spectrum of complex 1 in solid state (Figure S6a) showed that the ILCT transition is the only origin of single emission, and no visible contribution from such excited state in higher energy level (<335 nm, ν > 29 850 cm–1) was observed, because of the big energy gap (for ILCT: >8375 cm–1, >1.07 eV; for syn-dimer: or >10 985 cm–1, >1.36 eV). In contrast, different from that in complex 1, the BTD species was fixed in complex 2 with undulated layer structure to obviously weaken the influence of molecular vibrational deactivation; therefore, the fluorescence of excited state at higher energy level (375 nm, ν = 26 665 cm–1, d) was allowed. Moreover, under the irradiation of 360 nm, complex 2 only showed the emission from ππ* state (490 nm). Except for these, the excitation spectrum of ILCT transition (Figure S6b) also suggested that the internal conversion (IC) process from ππ* state to ILCT state was invalid in complex 2. At last, the lowest energy excited state of BTD anti-dimer was decayed in a non-irradiation way.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we surmised that, because mononuclear complex 1 is relatively flexible, the molecular vibrational deactivation was the main non-irradiation decay process of excited state in higher energy level. At the same time, the excitation spectrum of complex 1 in solid state (Figure S6a) showed that the ILCT transition is the only origin of single emission, and no visible contribution from such excited state in higher energy level (<335 nm, ν > 29850 cm-1) was observed, because of the big energy gap (for ILCT: >8375 cm-1, >1.07 eV; for syn-dimer: or >10985 cm-1, >1.36 eV). In contrast, different from that in complex 1, the BTD species was fixed in complex 2 with undulated layer structure to obviously weaken the influence of molecular vibrational deactivation; therefore, the fluorescence of excited state at higher energy level (375 nm, ν = 26665 cm-1, d) was allowed. Moreover, under the irradiation of 360 nm, complex 2 only showed the emission from ππ* state (490 nm). Except for these, the excitation spectrum of ILCT transition (Figure S6b) also suggested that the internal conversion (IC) process from ππ* state to ILCT state was invalid in complex 2. At last, the lowest energy excited state of BTD anti-dimer was decayed in a non-irradiation way.

elements.content: As we know, Britton–Robinson (BR) buffer solution with the broad modulation scale is a suitable choice as aqueous ambience to investagate the pH-response research in water ( and Figures S7 and S8). Because trace complex 1 can be soluble in water to form a dilute solution, before the actually pH-responsive behavior investigation of 1 in solid state, control experiment in aqueous solution was accomplished. As shown in Figure S7, the absorption spectra of 1 in the alkaline modulation scale of BR buffer solution was almost the same as the initially neutral one (pH = 7), whereas two absorption bands over 330 nm were visibly blue-shifted (1: from 353 to 343 nm; 2: from 465 to 420 nm) under acidic condition (pH = 2). However, as shown in a, emission intensity of 1 was distinctly weakened by increasing proton concentration, whereas such emission intensity (Figure S8) was sustainable from neutral (pH = 7) to alkaline condition (pH = 12). In acidic condition, the electron-withdrawing nature of tetrazole (initially deprotonated) was enhanced by partial protonation, which would weaken its electron-donating capabilty to further prompt the electron arrangement changes in the outer orbital of complex molecule; hence, it caused the hypsochromic absorption and quenched emission. Oppositely, because of the existence of deprotonated tetrazole, the deprotonation process hardly occurred in alkaline condition. Interestingly, as shown in Figure S9a, when the aqueous ambience was remodulated from acidic (pH = 2) to neutral (pH = 7), the absorption of complex 1 was totally recovered; furthermore, the reversible response was clearly observed under several circles, displaying the good regenerative capacity. At the same time, the emission experiment also proved such good regenerative capacity, where the reversible emission change was distinctly triggered by the external pH stimuli (b and Figure S9b). Moreover, it was further supported by the electrospray ionization–mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) experiment (Figure S10). This result is another evidence that the reversible optical response was originated from partial protonation/deprotonation of coordinated tetrazole group in different pH ambience.
elements.clean_text:
pH-Responsive Behavior of 1 and 2

As we know, Britton-Robinson (BR) buffer solution with the broad modulation scale is a suitable choice as aqueous ambience to investagate the pH-response research in water ( and Figures S7 and S8). Because trace complex 1 can be soluble in water to form a dilute solution, before the actually pH-responsive behavior investigation of 1 in solid state, control experiment in aqueous solution was accomplished. As shown in Figure S7, the absorption spectra of 1 in the alkaline modulation scale of BR buffer solution was almost the same as the initially neutral one (pH = 7), whereas two absorption bands over 330 nm were visibly blue-shifted (1: from 353 to 343 nm; 2: from 465 to 420 nm) under acidic condition (pH = 2). However, as shown in a, emission intensity of 1 was distinctly weakened by increasing proton concentration, whereas such emission intensity (Figure S8) was sustainable from neutral (pH = 7) to alkaline condition (pH = 12). In acidic condition, the electron-withdrawing nature of tetrazole (initially deprotonated) was enhanced by partial protonation, which would weaken its electron-donating capabilty to further prompt the electron arrangement changes in the outer orbital of complex molecule; hence, it caused the hypsochromic absorption and quenched emission. Oppositely, because of the existence of deprotonated tetrazole, the deprotonation process hardly occurred in alkaline condition. Interestingly, as shown in Figure S9a, when the aqueous ambience was remodulated from acidic (pH = 2) to neutral (pH = 7), the absorption of complex 1 was totally recovered; furthermore, the reversible response was clearly observed under several circles, displaying the good regenerative capacity. At the same time, the emission experiment also proved such good regenerative capacity, where the reversible emission change was distinctly triggered by the external pH stimuli (b and Figure S9b). Moreover, it was further supported by the electrospray ionization-mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) experiment (Figure S10). This result is another evidence that the reversible optical response was originated from partial protonation/deprotonation of coordinated tetrazole group in different pH ambience.

elements.content: (a) Emission spectra of 1 toward different pH values (pH < 7) in BR buffer solution. (b) The fluorescence reversibility of 1 in BR buffer solutions between pH = 7.0 and 2.0 at 537 nm (λex = 360 nm).
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Emission spectra of 1 toward different pH values (pH < 7) in BR buffer solution. (b) The fluorescence reversibility of 1 in BR buffer solutions between pH = 7.0 and 2.0 at 537 nm (λex = 360 nm).

elements.content: Unfortunately, when 1 was dispersed in different acidic media at room temperature, no visible emission quenching phenomenon was observed. However, when 2 was dispersed in different aqueous media at room temperature, there were some interesting emission changed phenomena depending on the changed pH values. In this case, complex 2 showed no response to the acidic environment, but it was sensitive with the alkaline environment. In detail, as shown in a, when 2 was dispersed in neutral-aqueous ambience, the relative proportion of dual-emission (ππ*: ILCT) was 0.87:1. Interestingly, when the ambience was changed to alkaline, such ratio became 2.96:1, indicating the enhanced ππ* emission (c). Herein, in comparison with the single fluorescence on–off response of 1 depending on the acidic condition, 2 exhibited the self-referencing fluorescence-response depending on the alkaline condition. This phenomenon was responding to the different coordination modes of tetrazole group between 1 and 2. As described before, in the case of 1, coordinated tetrazole was initially deprotonated, which was beneficial for the protonation process. In contrast, because of the existence of coordinated N3 –, coordinated tetrazole was close to neutral in the case of 2. Hence, comparing to the difficult protonation process in acidic condition, the deprotonation process easily occurred in alkaline condition. Furthermore, such deprotonation process would prompt the low ratio of IC that transferred the energy from the ππ* excited state to the ILCT excited state. More importantly, as shown in Figure S11, when the aqueous media was either from acidic to basic or from basic to acidic, the pH-dependent response of emission was almost reversible in the case of 2.
elements.clean_text: Unfortunately, when 1 was dispersed in different acidic media at room temperature, no visible emission quenching phenomenon was observed. However, when 2 was dispersed in different aqueous media at room temperature, there were some interesting emission changed phenomena depending on the changed pH values. In this case, complex 2 showed no response to the acidic environment, but it was sensitive with the alkaline environment. In detail, as shown in a, when 2 was dispersed in neutral-aqueous ambience, the relative proportion of dual-emission (ππ*: ILCT) was 0.87:1. Interestingly, when the ambience was changed to alkaline, such ratio became 2.96:1, indicating the enhanced ππ* emission (c). Herein, in comparison with the single fluorescence on-off response of 1 depending on the acidic condition, 2 exhibited the self-referencing fluorescence-response depending on the alkaline condition. This phenomenon was responding to the different coordination modes of tetrazole group between 1 and 2. As described before, in the case of 1, coordinated tetrazole was initially deprotonated, which was beneficial for the protonation process. In contrast, because of the existence of coordinated N3 -, coordinated tetrazole was close to neutral in the case of 2. Hence, comparing to the difficult protonation process in acidic condition, the deprotonation process easily occurred in alkaline condition. Furthermore, such deprotonation process would prompt the low ratio of IC that transferred the energy from the ππ* excited state to the ILCT excited state. More importantly, as shown in Figure S11, when the aqueous media was either from acidic to basic or from basic to acidic, the pH-dependent response of emission was almost reversible in the case of 2.

elements.content: Emission spectra of 2 that were dispersed in BR buffer solution with different pH values. pH = (a) 2, (b) 7, and (c) 12.
elements.clean_text: 6  Emission spectra of 2 that were dispersed in BR buffer solution with different pH values. pH = (a) 2, (b) 7, and (c) 12.

elements.content: In conclusion, two new benzothiadiazole-derived complexes 1 and 2 obtained by in situ click synthesis were investigated for the potential pH-responsive application. In this work, the connection between structure and photophysical property in such system was realized by the spectroscopic exploration and structural analysis. Especially, because of the different proton-withdrawing capability of coordinated tetrazole group, 1 showed the reversible fluorescence on–off responses in acidic ambience, whereas 2 exhibited the self-referencing fluorescence-response in an alkaline environment. This work opens a new strategy to develop the use and design of luminescent CP materials in selective pH detection.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, two new benzothiadiazole-derived complexes 1 and 2 obtained by in situ click synthesis were investigated for the potential pH-responsive application. In this work, the connection between structure and photophysical property in such system was realized by the spectroscopic exploration and structural analysis. Especially, because of the different proton-withdrawing capability of coordinated tetrazole group, 1 showed the reversible fluorescence on-off responses in acidic ambience, whereas 2 exhibited the self-referencing fluorescence-response in an alkaline environment. This work opens a new strategy to develop the use and design of luminescent CP materials in selective pH detection.

cln_elements.content: In this work, both complexes 1 and 2 showed the prolonged tails of absorption around 530 and 537 nm, respectively (). As described above, TBC is planar, which easily triggers the π–π stacking interaction in solid state. Especially, on the one hand, in complex 1 (Figure S4a), the organic linkers lie in parallel molecular planes to form the dimer in which the BTD units arrange in the same direction (syn-dimer of BTD; the transannular distance is of 3.39 Å). On the other hand, the dilute aqueous solution of complex 1 (Figure S5a) showed that there was a weak absorption at ∼465 nm resulting from the interligand charge transfer (ILCT) (π­(tetrazole) → π*­(BTD-CN)) transition, and over 500 nm no absorption band was observed. Hence, such absorption band around 530 nm (ν = 18 870 cm–1) is clearly resulted from the transition of syn-dimer. In contrast, as shown in Figure S4b, only the dimer in which the BTD units arrange in the opposite direction (anti-dimer of BTD; the transannular distance is of 3.37 Å). Such anti-dimer showed the slightly lower energy absorption band centered at 537 nm (ν = 18 620 cm–1), which was consistent with the reported case in 2010. Interestingly, comparing to small difference in absorption spectra, there was a significant difference of luminescence behavior between 1 and 2. As shown in a, complex 1 displayed the single emission, which was centered at 570 nm (ν = 17 540 cm–1). According to the excitation spectrum of 1 (Figure S6a), this emission is originated from the ILCT (π­(tetrazole) → π*­(BTD-CN)) transition, not the excited state of BTD syn-dimer species. Furthermore, without the contribution of BTD syn-dimer, the ILCT emission of 1 in water was hypsochromically shifted to 537 nm (ν = 18 620 cm–1, Figure S5b). However, 2 showed the totally different emission behavior (dual emission, b), where two emission peaks were centered at 490 (ν = 20 410 cm–1) and 568 nm (ν = 17 605 cm–1), respectively. Similarly, the former is ascribed to the π → π* state of monomeric BTD species (ππ* state), while the latter is resulted from the ILCT (π­(tetrazole) → π*­(BTD-CN)) state (Figure S6b). Besides, under the irradiation at 530 nm, neither 1 nor 2 shows the dimer emission. Because the large Stoke’s shift is common in BTD-based species, such emission was probably in near-infrared (NIR) range, which was easily quenched in concentrated solid state.
cln_elements.clean_text: In this work, both complexes 1 and 2 showed the prolonged tails of absorption around 530 and 537 nm, respectively (). As described above, TBC is planar, which easily triggers the π-π stacking interaction in solid state. Especially, on the one hand, in complex 1 (Figure S4a), the organic linkers lie in parallel molecular planes to form the dimer in which the BTD units arrange in the same direction (syn-dimer of BTD; the transannular distance is of 3.39 Å). On the other hand, the dilute aqueous solution of complex 1 (Figure S5a) showed that there was a weak absorption at ~465 nm resulting from the interligand charge transfer (ILCT) (π(tetrazole) → π*(BTD-CN)) transition, and over 500 nm no absorption band was observed. Hence, such absorption band around 530 nm (ν = 18870 cm-1) is clearly resulted from the transition of syn-dimer. In contrast, as shown in Figure S4b, only the dimer in which the BTD units arrange in the opposite direction (anti-dimer of BTD; the transannular distance is of 3.37 Å). Such anti-dimer showed the slightly lower energy absorption band centered at 537 nm (ν = 18 620 cm-1), which was consistent with the reported case in 2010. Interestingly, comparing to small difference in absorption spectra, there was a significant difference of luminescence behavior between 1 and 2. As shown in a, complex 1 displayed the single emission, which was centered at 570 nm (ν = 17540 cm-1). According to the excitation spectrum of 1 (Figure S6a), this emission is originated from the ILCT (π(tetrazole) → π*(BTD-CN)) transition, not the excited state of BTD syn-dimer species. Furthermore, without the contribution of BTD syn-dimer, the ILCT emission of 1 in water was hypsochromically shifted to 537 nm (ν = 18620 cm-1, Figure S5b). However, 2 showed the totally different emission behavior (dual emission, b), where two emission peaks were centered at 490 (ν = 20 410 cm-1) and 568 nm (ν = 17605 cm-1), respectively. Similarly, the former is ascribed to the π → π* state of monomeric BTD species (ππ* state), while the latter is resulted from the ILCT (π(tetrazole) → π*(BTD-CN)) state (Figure S6b). Besides, under the irradiation at 530 nm, neither 1 nor 2 shows the dimer emission. Because the large Stoke's shift is common in BTD-based species, such emission was probably in near-infrared (NIR) range, which was easily quenched in concentrated solid state.

metadata.title:
Interesting pH-Responsive Behavior in Benzothiadiazole-Derived
Coordination Polymer Constructed via an in Situ Click Synthesis
